DOC.brief_summary: This study will investigate if a single shot of spinal morphine will increase patient satisfaction when compared to intravenous morphine in Robot-Assisted Radical Prostatectomy
DOC.brief_title: Spinal Morphine in Robotic Assisted Radical Prostatectomy
DOC.detailed_description: This study is a randomized controlled trial. It will randomize 160 patients who are scheduled for Robot-Assisted Radical Prostatectomy. The intervention group will receive a single spinal injection of a bupivacaine (12,5 mg)/morphine(300 mcg) mixture. Controlgroup will receive a subcutaneous injection of lidoca√Øne for placebo purposes and an intravenous loading dose of morphine at the end of surgery. Both groups will receive general anesthesia during surgery in a standardized fashion. After the surgery, both groups will receive a Patient-Controlled Analgesia pump for post-operative pain control. Primary outcome is patient satisfaction as measured by the Quality-of-Recovery-15 questionnaire. This questionnaire will be taken at baseline, day 2 and 1 week after surgery. Secundary outcomes are morphine use per PCA, duration of hospital stay, side-effects and ease of surgery.
DOC.criteria: Scheduled for RobotAssisted Radical Prostatectomy Contraindications to spinal anesthesia (severe aortic stenosis, coagulation disorders) Contraindications to study medication (local anesthetics, morphine, paracetamol, metamizol) Conversion to an open procedure Postoperative ICUadmission
